event: Death of Albert Camus.
Publication of La dernière bande, suivi de Cendres by Editions de Minuit
Krapp’s Last Tape opens at the Provincetown Playhouse, New York, directed by Alan Schneider.
Insurrection in Algiers, known as “La semaine des barricades.”
The French Government takes on emergency powers to deal with the worsening situation in Algeria.
Générale of La dernière bande, directed by Blin, and Lettre morte, directed by Martin, Théâtre Récamier.
SB refuses a commission by R.B.D. French to write a play to benefit the Library, Trinity College Dublin.
SB’s tribute to Sean O’Casey published in The Irish Times.
Molloy, Malone Dies, and The Unnamable published by John Calder in a single volume as Three Novels.
The BBC Third Programme broadcasts Waiting For Godot.
SB lifts his embargo on production of his work in Ireland.
Attends Berliner Ensemble production of Brecht’s Die Mutter, Sarah Bernhardt Theatre, Paris; leaves at first opportunity.
Calder’s edition of Three Novels is seized from Hanna’s bookstore in Dublin, under Irish Government order.
SB attends, with Alan Schneider in Paris, the Berliner Ensemble production of Brecht’s Galileo.
Attends a run-through of Cyril Cusack’s production of Krapp’s Last Tape for the Théâtre des Nations, Paris.
Completes revision and typing of his new work, which becomes Comment c’est.
Dates a draft of what becomes Happy Days.
Writes his first letter to Harold Pinter.
The BBC Third Programmme broadcasts The Old Tune, produced by Barbara Bray, with Jack MacGowran and Patrick Magee.
Vérité-Liberté publishes a Déclaration sur le Droit à l’Insoumission dans la Guerre d’Algérie signed by 121 writers and artists; it becomes known as the Manifeste des 121.
Pinget’s La Manivelle and SB’s English text, The Old Tune, Editions de Minuit (copyright registered).
SB works on translation of “L’Expulsé” with Richard Seaver, in Paris.
Jérôme Lindon arrested.
A letter condemning the “apologists of desertion and disobedience” and defending the army appears in Le Figaro with 185 signatories.
Has begun to move into his new apartment at 38 Boulevard Saint-Jacques, Paris 14.
De Gaulle outlines his conception of the “Algerian Republic.”
John F. Kennedy is elected President of the United States.
SB views On the Bowery directed by Lionel Rogosin.
With A. J. Leventhal, SB attends Max Frisch’s Biedermann et les incendiaires, Théâtre de Lutèce, directed by Jean-Marie Serreau.
Meeting with Sylvia Beach and other authors who contributed to Our Exagmination (1929) to receive lettered copies and limited first edition.
The French proposal for Algerian self-determination receives 75 percent of the votes in a referendum.
Comment c’est published by Editions de Minuit.
Opening of Henri Hayden’s exhibition at Waddington Gallery, London.
SB’s first meeting with Harold Pinter.
SB dates completion of a draft of Happy Days. Begins revision (dated 16 January - 2 February 1961).
Attends Pinter’s Le Gardien.
Attends concert performance of Mihalovici’s opera Krapp at the Théâtre de Chaillot.
Attends dress rehearsal of Mihalovici’s opera Krapp in Bielefeld, Germany.
Attends Suhrkamp evening in Frankfurt.
Returns to Paris, driving with the Tophovens, having visited Amsterdam, Delft, and Haarlem.
Resident in Folkestone prior to his marriage to Suzanne Deschevaux-Dumesnil.
SB and Suzanne marry in the Folkestone Register Office, and return to Paris.
WNTA TV (New York) broadcasts Waiting for Godot directed by Alan Schneider.
SB manages rehearsals of En attendant Godot in Blin’s absence in London.
Trial of Adolf Eichmann begins in Jerusalem.
Yuri Gagarin, aboard the Soviet satellite Vostok 1, becomes the first human in outer space.
Bay of Pigs “invasion” of Cuba by US.
Attempted coup, in Algiers, by Generals Challe, Salan, Jouhaud, and Zeller, against De Gaulle’s policy of self-determination for Algeria.
Cuba declares itself a Democratic Socialist Republic.
Opening of En attendant Godot, Théâtre de l’Odéon.

SB awarded the first Prix International des Editeurs, (also known later as the Prix Formentor, and the Prix International de Littérature) shared with Jorge Luis Borges; SB does not attend the ceremony.
Barbara Bray and her daughters have moved to Paris.
SB in Surrey with Sheila and Donald Page until 22 or 23 June, then in London.
Attends an England vs. Australia Test Match at Lord’s, London, with Donald Page and cousin Molly Roe.
BBC TV broadcasts Waiting for Godot directed by Donald McWhinnie.
SB attends Glyndebourne performance of Donizetti’s L’Elisir d’amore.
The Bielefeld production of Mihalovici’s opera of Krapp performed as part of the Théâtre des Nations, Paris.
SB attends John Osborne’s Luther performed as part of the Théâtre des Nations, Paris.
Finds his Ussy cottage has been broken into during his absence.
Begins English translation of Comment c’est.
Increasingly frequent OAS attacks in many areas of France.
The German Democratic Republic (GDR) begins construction of the Berlin Wall.
SB in Etretat.
SB in England.
Failed attempt on the life of General de Gaulle.
World premiere of Happy Days at the Cherry Lane Theatre, New York, directed by Alan Schneider.
Opening of Bram van Velde’s retrospective, Knoedler Gallery, Paris.
SB writes a draft of Words and Music, planned for music by John Beckett and presentation on the BBC.
SB’s Poems in English published by John Calder.
SB sends petition to John Calder and Harold Hobson for signatures to protest against the trial of Jérôme Lindon for his publication of Le Déserteur and for his anti-torture position on Algeria.
SB in Ussy to complete draft translation of Comment c’est (How It Is).
Demonstration against the OAS at the Charonne Métro Station provokes police response that ends in death of nine persons; this triggers a general strike in Paris on 13 February in Paris.
Jean-Jacques Mayoux’s home is bombed.
Bram van Velde’s first New York exhibition opens, Knoedler Gallery.
With the signing of the Evian Accords, a ceasefire takes effect in Algeria on 19 March.
With Roger Blin, SB attends Mary Manning Howe’s play The Voice of Shem in the Gate Theatre production as part of the Théâtre des Nations, Paris.
Attends Henri Hayden vernissage, Galerie Suillerot.
Attends vernissage of Joan Mitchell double show, Galerie Jacques Dubourg and Galerie Lawrence, Paris.
Has begun work on a play for three faces and lights (ultimately, Play).
Lunches with the Stravinskys in Paris.
The BBC Third Programme broadcasts Endgame, directed by Alan Gibson.
Faber and Faber publish Happy Days.
Agreement signed between the Algerian FLN (National Liberation Front) and the OAS effectively ends the Algerian war.
After the approval of the Evian Accords by the electorate of Algeria, De Gaulle pronounces Algeria an independent country.
SB finishes draft of new play (Play).
Attends Pinget double bill of La Manivelle and Architruc at the Comédie de Paris.
Holidays with Suzanne in Kitzbühel. Returns to Paris on 25 August.
Second attempt on the life of General de Gaulle.
De Gaulle dissolves the French National Assembly, now allowing the President to be directly elected by the people.
SB sends complete manuscripts of Cascando to Herbert Myron for deposit in the Harvard University Theatre Collection.
Arrives in London to begin rehearsals of Happy Days on 8 October.
Attends Jack McGowran’s run-through of his one-man Beckett show, End of the Day.  The BBC Third Programme broadcasts Words and Music.
Start of the Cuban missile crisis.
SB attends recital by Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau singing Hugo Wolf songs, Royal Festival Hall.
Spends the weekend at Sheila and Donald Page’s home in Surrey.
London opening of Happy Days at the Royal Court Theatre. SB returns to Paris. SB grants George Devine and the Royal Court Theatre first option on production of his future work in London.
Consults an eye specialist in Berne.
The BBC Third Programme broadcasts Words and Music.
Henri Hayden taken ill and hospitalized in London,
SB attends Ionesco’s Le Roi se meurt with George Devine, Jocelyn Herbert, and her daughter Jenny.
Attends with Robert Pinget, Roland Dubillard’s La Maison d’os.
SB attends party in honor of Pinget at the home of the Lindons.
Tous ceux qui tombent broadcast on French Television with an introduction by Georges Belmont.
SB accepts Barney Rosset’s commission to write a film.
Grove Press publish Poems in English.
SB attends Ramón Valle-Inclán’s play Divines paroles at the Théâtre de l’Odéon, directed by Roger Blin.
Jean-Jacques Mayoux speaks on SB’s work on France III radio.
SB begins a manuscript notebook of Film.
Completes first draft of Film.
Works with Jean-Marie Serreau on Comédie.
Attends King Lear directed by Peter Brook at the Théâtre Sarah-Bernhardt.
Agrees to an embargo against performance of his plays before segregated audiences in South Africa.
Attends rehearsals and recordings of Cascando, RTF studios.
With Alan Schneider, attends two working sessions of Spiel in Ulm, Germany.
Death of Pope John XXIII.
Premiere of Spiel at the Ulmer-Theater, Ulm-Donau, directed by Deryk Mendel.
SB rehearses Comédie with Madeleine Renaud and Roger Blin.
Holidays with Suzanne in Zell-am-See, Austria, leaving on 15 July via Innsbruck to arrive in Paris on 16 July.
Election of Cardinal Montini as Pope Paul VI.
SB begins to translate “Texte pour rien 13.”
A. J. Leventhal moves from Dublin to Paris.
SB writes a brief tribute to Richard Aldington.
Begins a play for a lit face (“Kilcool”).
Oh les beaux jours has its premiere at the Teatro del Ridotto, directed by Roger Blin, with Madeleine Renaud, as part of the Venice Festival.
Happy Days opens at the Eblana Theatre, Dublin, directed by John Beary, with Marie Kean.
RTF broadcasts Cascando.
SB asks Faber and Faber to publish the unexpurgated version of Waiting for Godot.
Assassination of John F. Kennedy. Lyndon B. Johnson becomes President of the United States.
Play opens at the Cherry Lane Theatre, New York, directed by Alan Schneider, on a double bill with Pinter’s The Lover.
SB in London for rehearsals of Endgame with Patrick Magee and Jack MacGowran.
Attends playback of Cascando, as recorded in Stuttgart.
Attends the opening night of Max Frisch’s play Andorra at the Old Vic.
Attends Theatre of Cruelty productions organized by Charles Marowitz and Peter Brook, at LAMDA.
Attends dress rehearsal of Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf, directed by Alan Schneider, Piccadilly Theatre.
Endgame with MacGowran and Magee opens at the Studio des Champs-Elysées.
SB declines Goddard Lieberson’s invitation to contribute to a Homage for John F. Kennedy.
In London for rehearsals of Play.
Spends weekend with George Devine and Jocelyn Herbert at their farm, “Andrews,” in Hampshire.
Play opens at the National Theatre, Old Vic, on a double bill with Sophocles’ Philoctetes.
SB returns from London to Paris.
Writes tribute to Brendan Behan for Theater heute.
Resumes rehearsals for Comédie, directed by Serreau.
Gisèle Freund photographs SB.
John Calder (Publisher) Ltd. publish How It Is.
Henri Cartier-Bresson photographs SB in Paris.
Les Lettres Nouvelles publish Comédie.
Comédie opens at the Pavillon de Marsan, as part of the Estival 1964, directed by Jean-Marie Serreau assisted by SB.
Nelson Mandela sentenced to life imprisonment in South Africa.
SB in London to assist director Donald McWhinnie with rehearsals of Endgame for the Aldwych Theatre.
Endgame opens at the Aldwych produced by the Royal Shakespeare Company.
SB flies from London to New York for work on Film.
Murphy, published by John Calder (Publisher) Ltd., is banned in Ireland.
SB stays at Barney Rosset’s home in East Hampton, works with Alan Schneider and cameraman Boris Kaufman on plans for Film.
Shooting of Film begins on location in New York.
SB attends Dutchman by LeRoi Jones (later Amiri Baraka) and The American Dream by Edward Albee at Cherry Lane Theatre.
Final day of shooting of Film.
SB works with Sidney Meyers, the editor of Film.
Flies to Paris.
Death of Leslie Daiken, in London.
SB has begun to write first of four pieces which will later be called “Faux départs.”
Death of Sean O’Casey.
BBC Third Programme broadcasts Cascando, with Patrick Magee and Denys Hawthorne.
SB halts publication of More Pricks Than Kicks by Grove Press and Calder.
SB in London for rehearsals of Waiting for Godot, directed by Anthony Page at the Royal Court Theatre.
Jean-Paul Sartre refuses the Nobel Prize in Literature.
Waiting for Godot opens at the Royal Court Theatre with Patrick Magee and Nicol Williamson.
SB returns to Paris from London.
SB sends completed manuscript of Come and Go to Barbara Bray.
SB called to Berlin to help with Schiller-Theater production of Warten auf Godot, directed by Deryk Mendel.
Flies from Berlin to London to assist with rehearsals of Jack MacGowran’s Beginning to End.
Attends Marat/Sade, by Peter Weiss, directed by Peter Brook, with Patrick Magee as the Marquis de Sade.
Returns to Berlin from London to resume rehearsals of Warten auf Godot.
Flies from Berlin to Paris.
Learns that Italian actress Clara Colosimo has gone on hunger strike because she cannot get permission to perform Giorni felici (Happy Days).
Launch of Operation Rolling Thunder, a sustained American bombing campaign of North Vietnam that lasts until 2 November 1968
SB views latest cut of Film and sends his notes on to Schneider the following day.
Death of Nancy Cunard in Paris.
SB completes a draft of Va-et-vient, French translation of Come and Go.
Sends third and fourth (final) draft of How It Is to Henry Wenning as a gift to the University of Boston Beckett collection.
SB begins draft of Eh Joe for television.
Faber and Faber publish unexpurgated edition of Waiting for Godot.
SB completes Eh Joe and sends to MacGowran, Donald McWhinnie, and Curtis Brown.
SB and Suzanne fly to Turin, travelling on to Courmayeur on 22 June for a holiday.
SB completes the French translation Dis Joe.
Translates Imagination morte imaginez into English.
Returns to Paris from Courmayeur via Turin.
Opening of the Mont Blanc Tunnel.
SB has surgery on jaw.
Begins French translation of Words and Music; draft translation completed on 14 August.
Premiere of Film at the Venice Film Festival. SB begins draft of Assez.
SB attends rehearsals of Pinget’s L’Hypothèse performed by Pierre Chabert.
Begins revisions of Assez.
Pinget’s L’Hypothèse performed by Pierre Chabert at the Musée Moderne (Biennale de Paris).
Annales (Toulouse) publishes an extract from Mercier et Camier (hitherto unpublished novel, 1946).
SB in Ussy, resting and working on Le Dépeupleur. Completes first draft on 28 November.
Begins work with director Marin Karmitz on a film of Comédie.
Attends performance of Des journées entières dans les arbres by Marguerite Duras.
Charles de Gaulle is reelected as French President, defeating François Mitterrand.
SB working with Jean-Marie Serreau on film of Comédie.
Comédie et actes divers (Comédie, Va et vient, Cascando, Paroles et musique, Dis Joe, Acte sans paroles II) printed for Editions de Minuit.
Death of Alberto Giacometti.
A Beckett-Abend directed by Deryk Mendel at the Schiller-Theater-Werkstatt, Berlin (Alle, die da fallen, Kommen und Gehen, and Akte ohne Worte II).
Death of George Devine in London.
Tours Film Festival awards Prix Spécial du Jury to Film.
SB in London for the recording of Eh Joe, and of his poems.
Assez printed for Editions de Minuit.
Spectacle Beckett-Ionesco-Pinget (BIP) opens at Odéon-Théâtre de France: Va et vient, Comédie, Robert Pinget’s L’Hypothèse, Eugène Ionesco’s La Lacune and Délire à deux.
SB’s poems broadcast on the BBC Third Programme.
SB and Suzanne in Santa Margherita Ligure.
First issue of La Quinzaine littéraire (Paris).
SB travels to Stuttgart to direct He Joe with Deryk Mendel at Süddeutscher Rundfunk (SDR).
SB rehearses Eh Joe with Madeleine Renaud and Jean-Louis Barrault.
SB gives Ruby Cohn his Dr. Johnson notes.
In Ussy for the first time in four months.
SB’s cataracts diagnosed.
SB and Suzanne travel to Courmayeur, staying until 6 July. SB works intermittently on Le Dépeupleur.
Eh Joe broadcast on BBC TV2.
Ludovic and Agnès Janvier have translated From an Abandoned Work as D’un ouvrage abandonné in consultation with SB.
Death of SB’s sister-in-law, Jean Beckett. SB attends funeral in Ireland and remains there until 3 September.
SB “re-rehearses” Comédie and Va et Vient for new season at Odéon-Théâtre de France.
SB and Suzanne on holiday in Greece. They return to Paris via Athens.
Play broadcast on the BBC Third Programme.
Bing printed for Editions de Minuit.
SB completes English translation of Texts for Nothing for inclusion in No’s Knife, a collection to be published by John Calder.
SB has written, “Siège remis devant le dehors imprenable” for the catalogue of Avigdor Arikha’s exhibition at the Galerie Claude Bernard.
SB and Suzanne in Portugal.
SB and Suzanne return to Paris from Portugal.
SB completes D’un ouvrage abandonné with the Janviers. Begins work with them on French translation of Watt.
In Ussy, where he takes delivery of a Schimmel upright piano.
Têtes-Mortes printed for Editions de Minuit.
SB falls into garage pit at Ussy, breaking two ribs.
Film shown at the Cinéma la Pagode (Paris), with film of Comédie.
Death of Thomas MacGreevy in Dublin.
Jack MacGowran’s reading of Imagination Dead Imagine broadcast on the BBC Third Programme, introduced by Barbara Bray.
SB in Berlin to consult with Schiller Theater on Endspiel.
No’s Knife published by John Calder.
SB with Suzanne in Sardinia.
In Berlin, for Endspiel rehearsals that begin on 18 August.
Receives request from the Arrabals to give testimony at Arrabal’s trial in Spain.
Meets Theodor Adorno in Berlin.
Endspiel opens at the Schiller-Theater-Werkstatt.
SB returns to Paris from Berlin.
SB and Suzanne in Sardinia.
SB consults Dr. Goldmann, an eye specialist in Berne.
Burial of Suzanne Beckett’s mother.
SB refuses permission for a film of Waiting for Godot with Jack MacGowran, to be directed by Roman Polanski.
SB learns that Stuart Maguinness has nominated him for the Nobel Prize in Literature.
Learns of the death of Nancy Sinclair Cusack.
Premiere of Come and Go, Peacock Theatre, Dublin.
SB has finished the French translation of Watt.
Declines an invitation from Esquire magazine to “report” on the Democratic Convention in Chicago.
Death of Peggy Beckett, mother of John, Ann, and Peter Beckett, in Dublin.
SB in Dublin to attend funeral (his last visit to Ireland).
Assassination of Martin Luther King, Jr.
SB’s cousins (John and Vera Beckett, Deirdre Hamilton, and Ann Beckett) in Paris at his invitation.
Fin de Partie opens at the Alpha-347. Opening of Henri Hayden retrospective at the Musée National d’Art Moderne.
Street fights in Paris: the beginning of “les événements de mai 68.”
“Nuit des barricades” in the Latin Quarter. Students clash with Police, hundreds injured.
Students occupy the Théâtre de l’Odéon.
Visat print SB’s L’Issue with engravings by Avigdor Arikha.
Death of Robert Kennedy, who had been shot in Los Angeles on 5 June.
SB is diagnosed with lung abscess. Cancels plans to be in England in July.
Declines nomination by Enid Starkey for the Chair of Poetry at the University of Oxford.
Reports gradual improvement in his health.
Meets Ezra Pound and Olga Rudge in Paris.
Death of Marcel Duchamp in Paris.
Death of Estella Solomons in Dublin.
SB attends opening of Bram van Velde’s exhibition at the Galerie Knoedler, Paris.
SB and Suzanne leave Paris for Madeira.
Come and Go performed at the Royal Festival Hall, London, in support of Arts Against Censorship.
SB and Suzanne leave Funchal for Porto Santo.
Apollo 8 launched to orbit the moon.
French translation of Watt printed for Minuit.
SB and Suzanne in Porto Santo.
Death of Stuart Gilbert in Paris.
Richard Nixon inaugurated as President of the United States.
Fin de partie ends its run at Théâtre 347.
SB and Suzanne leave Porto Santo for Cascais.
SB and Suzanne return to Paris.
SB works with Elmar Tophoven on script of Das letzte Band.
Informs Siegfried Unseld that he does not wish to receive the Nobel Prize.
Charles de Gaulle steps down as President of France.
Georges Pompidou takes over as President of France.
Film published by Grove Press.
Neil Armstrong takes first steps on the moon, as part of the Apollo 11 mission.
SB meets Buckminster Fuller to see his design for the proposed Samuel Beckett Theatre in Oxford.
The Woodstock Festival is held in upstate New York.
SB flies to Berlin to direct Das letzte Band at the Schiller Theater.
Barbara Bray in Berlin.
Das letzte Band opens at the Schiller Theater.
SB flies from Berlin to Tunis, where he meets Suzanne. They later travel on to Hammamet.
SB and Suzanne move to Nabeul.
Sans printed for Editions de Minuit.
Mass demonstrations across the United States against the war in Vietnam.
SB awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature.
Death of Sidney Meyers in New York.
Jérôme Lindon represents SB in Stockholm at the Nobel Prize ceremonies.
SB and Suzanne travel from Nabeul to Cascais, Portugal.
